Amazon's business model has shifted significantly since its launch as an online bookstore in 1995. Over the years, the company has expanded its product offerings beyond books and now sells almost anything and everything online. Some of the significant shifts in Amazon's business model are as follows:

1. Diversification of product offering: Amazon started as an online bookstore, but over the years, it has expanded its product offerings to include a wide range of products such as electronics, clothing, home goods, and groceries.

2. Introduction of Amazon Prime: In 2005, Amazon introduced its loyalty program, Amazon Prime, which offers customers free two-day shipping, streaming of movies and TV shows, and access to exclusive deals.

3. Expansion of Amazon Web Services: In 2006, Amazon launched Amazon Web Services (AWS), which is a cloud computing platform that provides various services such as storage, computing power, and databases to businesses.

4. Brick-and-mortar stores: In recent years, Amazon has opened brick-and-mortar stores, including bookstores, convenience stores, and grocery stores, to expand its physical presence.

5. Focus on artificial intelligence (AI) and automation: Amazon has invested heavily in AI and automation technology to enhance its supply chain, delivery systems, and customer experience. The company uses AI to improve product recommendations, optimize pricing, and automate warehouse operations.

Overall, Amazon's business model has shifted over time to become much more diversified, focusing on offering a vast selection of products, providing exceptional customer service, and leveraging technology to improve its operations.
